What are the best-selling smartphones in Q3 2024?

November 8, 2024  13:50

The basic iPhone 15 has become the leader in global smartphone sales in the third quarter of 2024. This is stated in the report of the research company Counterpoint Research.

The second and third places were taken by the more expensive iPhone 15 Pro Max and iPhone 15 Pro. Moreover, as analysts note, Pro models accounted for half of iPhone sales in the third quarter for the first time.

Samsung's Galaxy A series of smartphones, known for their affordable prices and long software support, took four places in the top ten most popular devices thanks to their popularity in growing markets and their focus on affordable models. Thus, the fourth to seventh places were occupied by: Galaxy A15 4G, A15 5G, A35 5G and Galaxy A05 smartphones.

Meanwhile, the base model of Samsung's flagship Galaxy S24 series remains in tenth place and is in the top ten for the third quarter in a row. According to experts, this is the first time since 2018 that the Galaxy S model has appeared in the top ten of global sales.

iPhone 14 and Xiaomi Redmi 13C took the eighth and ninth places.

Nvidia exceeds $3.6 trillion market value

November 8, 2024  10:14

Shares of Nvidia registered a record growth, as a result of which the chip maker became the first in history, the market value of which exceeded 3.6 trillion dollars, reports Reuters․

Shares in the artificial intelligence chip maker rose 2.2% on Thursday, boosted by investors' optimistic expectations of tax cuts and looser regulations following Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election.

The market value of Nvidia's stock was $3.65 trillion at the end of the day, surpassing Apple's high of $3.57 trillion, which was recorded on October 21. Nvidia has actually overtaken Apple to become the world's most valuable company, according to LSEG.

Apple shares also rose 2.1% on Thursday, giving the company a market value of $3.44 trillion.

At the moment, Nvidia is the largest company on the US stock market and is winning the race between Microsoft, Alphabet and other heavyweights. The company's shares rose 12% in November, tripling in value this year.

After this year's gains, Nvidia's market value now exceeds that of Eli Lilly, Walmart, JPMorgan, Visa, UnitedHealth Group and Netflix combined.

Analysts predict that Nvidia will increase its quarterly revenue by more than 80% to $32.9 billion when it reports its results on November 20;

In June, Nvidia briefly became the world's most valuable company, before being overtaken by Microsoft and Apple.

Microsoft's market value is about $3.16 trillion, and its stock rose 1.25% on Thursday.

Scientists have created a texture that accurately conveys tactile sensations

November 7, 2024  22:18

Researchers at Northwestern University (USA) have developed a high-tech patch that allows users to experience a wide range of tactile sensations, from gentle touches and strokes to firm pressure and stretching. This invention has applications in both entertainment, such as providing feedback in virtual reality, and in healthcare, by helping visually impaired people better navigate their surroundings.

The patch prototype consists of a hexagonal silicone base with 19 actuators, which can vibrate or press on the skin at the point of contact. The main innovation lies in the actuators, which are noted for their record-breaking energy efficiency.

The actuators receive signals from a smartphone via Bluetooth, with each containing a miniature battery. Software controls the sequence and mode of actuator activation to transmit specific tactile sensations to the skin. The researchers have designed a solution that allows the actuators to maintain two stable states without consuming energy. This feature is especially valuable for long-term wear.

According to the researchers, they harnessed the natural elasticity of human skin. When the actuator applies pressure, the skin compresses and remains in a tense state until a release command is given, at which point the actuator switches to the opposite state using only the stored compression force and without additional energy.

In addition to delivering tactile sensations for games and virtual experiences, the proposed tactile patch offers visually impaired individuals a form of "basic vision." It acts as a substitute for the cane they use to sense their surroundings. Now, a smartphone's LiDAR sensor can perform this task, transmitting coded information to the patch’s sensors. Experiments on volunteers have shown that the system works effectively and can replace a cane, making life more convenient for people with poor or no vision.

Canada has demanded the closure of TikTok's office in the country

November 7, 2024  20:04

The Canadian government has demanded that TikTok Technology Canada cease operations in the country due to national security risks. This is reported by The Wall Street Journal.

Canadian authorities have not clarified what national security threat the work of TikTok's local office poses. TikTok, for its part, has said that closing local offices and cutting "hundreds" of jobs "is not in anyone's best interest." The social network owned by the Chinese company ByteDance plans to challenge this decision of the Canadian government.

It is noted that, despite this requirement, the Canadian authorities will not block users' access to the application and will not prohibit them from publishing content.

Michael Geist, a professor of internet law at the University of Ottawa, believes that banning TikTok's office, but not the app, can only make the situation worse, as the risks associated with the service will not disappear, but it will be more difficult to hold the company accountable.

Last year, Canada already banned the use of TikTok on government officials' devices due to security concerns.

TikTok is also facing problems in the US, where it has not been completely banned, but significant steps have been taken to restrict its use, again citing national security concerns. The US government has long been concerned about TikTok's ties to China, as it is owned by the Chinese company ByteDance. There are concerns that user data may be accessible to the Chinese government.

In 2020, then-President Donald Trump's administration issued executive orders in an attempt to ban TikTok. These orders were later revoked by the Joe Biden administration. On April 24, 2024, Biden signed legislation requiring ByteDance to either sell TikTok to an American company or shut down the app within a year. ByteDance considers the law unconstitutional and has appealed it.

Nissan will lay off 9,000 people, reduce production

November 7, 2024  16:07

Nissan Motor Company has announced that it plans to implement various measures to reduce costs, within the framework of which 9,000 jobs will be cut.

The company also cut its full-year forecast for the second time in a row this year as it continues to struggle in major markets such as China. The automaker will also reduce global production capacity by 20%.

"These turnaround measures do not mean that the company is downsizing," the company's Chief Executive Officer Makoto Uchida said in the earnings and loss report. "Nissan will restructure its business to become more economical and sustainable, as well as restructure its management to respond quickly and flexibly to changes in the business environment," he added.

The company lowered its forecast for operating profit for the fiscal year to $974.9 million. In July-September, the operating profit decreased by 85% compared to the previous year.

Earlier it became known that the German car manufacturer Volkswagen decided to close at least three factories and cut tens of thousands of jobs in all other factories. It will be the first time in the company's 87-year history that Volkswagen plants are closing in its home country. Currently, VW has 10 factories in Germany and about 300,000 employees.

Japanese scientists sent the first wooden satellite into space

November 7, 2024  18:05

Japanese scientists have sent a wooden satellite into space for the first time in the world, which may change the practice of using materials in this field, writes The New York Times.

It took them years to develop the cube-shaped satellite, which was launched into space on a SpaceX rocket from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Starting in December, it will spend six months in low Earth orbit.

A group of Kyoto University researchers came up with the LignoSat concept in collaboration with the Japanese lumber company Sumitomo Forestry. Their goal is to test how renewable materials such as wood are preserved in space, where there are extreme climatic conditions, harmful cosmic rays and energetic solar particles. In addition, scientists hope that the new satellite will not leave additional pollutants in the atmosphere.

"Before, no one had thought of using wood in rocket science," Koji Murata, professor of forestry and biomaterials science at Kyoto University, which worked on the satellite, told the newspaper. :

In the early 1900s, wood was a common building material for airplanes, so Murata thought it could also be used for satellites. Japanese engineer and former NASA astronaut Takao Doi raised this question in 2017 and has been testing this theory ever since. In 2022, they began by sending wood samples from three different types of trees (birch, cherry and magnolia) to the International Space Station.

Each of the samples spent eight months in space and surprisingly, the researchers found no signs of wood decay or surface damage. In the end, the team decided to make their model out of magnolia wood, which is known for its light weight and least chance of cracking.

Two carpenters from Kyoto then created LignoSat's wooden components, consisting of plastic and silicone parts. They assembled the cube using a traditional Japanese crafting technique that doesn't require any screws or glue. Unlike metal, wood can shrink when it loses moisture, so this is something scientists still need to investigate, as well as how well the satellite can measure Earth's magnetic field.

Six months later, the decommissioned satellite will re-enter Earth's atmosphere and burn up. If it were a metal satellite, it would emit tiny particles of aluminum oxide that can damage the ozone layer. But because it is made of wood, the satellite will emit water vapor and carbon dioxide.

Looking ahead, Murata has ambitious plans for the future. "I hope to grow wood on Mars," he said. "At one time I thought it was impossible to send anything made of wood into space."

NASA releases highest-quality images of Jupiter in entire history of observations

November 7, 2024  12:16

The US National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has published the photos of Jupiter, which are the best in the history of observations of this gas giant. The photos were taken by the Juno probe during its 66th flyby of the fifth planet of the solar system.

The Juno spacecraft was launched in 2011 and reached Jupiter five years later in 2016, traveling a distance of 2.735 billion kilometers. Since then, the probe has regularly flown past Jupiter and its moons and photographed them, then beamed the data back to Earth.

During the last flight of the gas giant, the probe took the highest quality photos of the planet. For example, he drew a close-up of the north pole of Jupiter (a central cyclone was found in this region, surrounded by eight other cyclones, each of which is about 4000 km in diameter).

Juno also photographed Jupiter's most famous storm, the Great Red Spot. If it was twice the size of Earth in 1979, now it is "only" 1.3 times the size of our planet. Data obtained by Juno showed that the depth of the Great Red Spot storm is about 320 km. The probe also recorded large cyclones as it flew over the gas giant's south pole.

Musk's wealth increases by 26.5 billion dollars

November 7, 2024  10:28

American entrepreneur and Tesla CEO Elon Musk's fortune increased by $26.5 billion after the company's shares rose 15% amid the US presidential election, according to data from the Bloomberg Billionaires Index (BBI).

According to the results of the market on Wednesday, Tesla's shares rose by 14.75%, thanks to which Musk's wealth increased. With a fortune of 290 billion dollars, he still occupies the first place in the BBI ranking.

In the US presidential elections, which were held on November 5, the Republican candidate, former president Donald Trump, won, who announced before the elections that if he was elected, his closest supporters, billionaire Elon Musk and politician Robert Kennedy Jr., would be given positions. will give in the future administration.

Donald Trump's victory was announced at around 02:00 Washington time. Then in Florida, Trump addressed his supporters with a speech, announced his victory, and also talked about what needs to be done.

Trump has widened his lead over incumbent Vice President Kamala Harris, according to Fox News' updated forecast. According to the calculations of the TV channel, the Republican candidate received 295 voters' votes, out of a total of 538. Harris received 226 votes. Trump has also surpassed Harris in the calculation of the citizens themselves. In particular, he received more than 72.6 million votes, and Harris - about 68 million votes.

Samsung introduces W25 and W25 Flip foldable smartphones: What features do they have?

November 7, 2024  14:17

Samsung introduced the latest smartphones, W25 Flip and W25, at an event in China. These are special editions of the Galaxy Z Flip 6 and Galaxy Z Fold, customized for the Chinese market. Both devices feature a matte black ceramic body with the Heart to the World logo and a durable gold-toned aluminum frame. They are powered by the Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 for Galaxy processor and run Android 14 with the One UI 6.1.1 interface.

The Samsung W25 is equipped with an 8-inch Dynamic AMOLED 2X display with a resolution of 2184 × 1968 pixels, HDR10+ support, peak brightness of 2600 nits, and an adaptive refresh rate from 1 to 120 Hz. It also has a 6.5-inch outer Dynamic AMOLED 2X display with the same peak brightness and adaptive refresh rate, protected by Corning Gorilla Glass Victus 2.

The device runs on an octa-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 for Galaxy processor clocked at 3.4 GHz, with an Adreno 750 GPU. It includes 16 GB of LPDDR5X RAM and UFS 4.0 storage options of 512 GB or 1 TB, and supports dual nano-SIM cards.

The main camera has a 200-megapixel sensor with optical image stabilization, complemented by a 12-megapixel ultra-wide camera (123˚, f/2.2), a 10-megapixel camera with 3x optical zoom (f/2.4), a 10-megapixel front camera (f/2.2), and a 4-megapixel camera under the inner screen (f/1.8).

The folded dimensions are 157.9 × 72.8 × 10.6 mm, and 157.9 × 142.6 × 4.9 mm when unfolded, weighing 255 g. The fingerprint scanner is located on the side, and the device is IP48 rated for water and dust resistance. Connectivity options include 5G, Dual 4G VoLTE, Wi-Fi 6E 802.11 (2.4/5 GHz), Bluetooth 5.3, GPS with GLONASS support, USB Type-C, and NFC. The 4400 mAh battery supports 25W wired charging, 15W wireless charging, and 4.5W reverse wireless charging.

The Samsung W25 Flip has a 6.7-inch Dynamic AMOLED 2X Infinity Flex display with a resolution of 2640 × 1080 pixels and an adaptive refresh rate from 1 to 120 Hz. It also has an external 3.4-inch Super AMOLED display with a resolution of 720 × 748 pixels and a 60 Hz refresh rate, protected by Corning Gorilla Glass Victus 2.

The device is powered by an octa-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 3 for Galaxy processor clocked at 3.4 GHz with an Adreno 750 GPU. It comes with 12 GB of LPDDR5X RAM and 512 GB of UFS 4.0 storage, and supports dual nano-SIM cards.

The main camera setup includes a 50-megapixel primary sensor with optical stabilization (f/1.8) and a 12-megapixel ultra-wide camera with a 123° field of view (f/2.2). The front-facing camera has a 10-megapixel sensor (f/2.2).

Connectivity features include support for 5G, 4G, Wi-Fi 6E 802.11 ax (2.4 GHz + 5 GHz), Bluetooth 5.3 LE, USB Type-C, NFC, and GPS. The device is IP48 rated for water and dust resistance and has stereo speakers with Dolby Atmos support via USB Type-C.

Its folded dimensions are 85.1 × 71.9 × 14.9 mm, and 165.1 × 71.9 × 6.9 mm when unfolded, weighing 187 g. The 4000 mAh battery supports 25W wired charging, 15W wireless charging, and reverse wireless charging.

The Samsung W25 is priced at 15,999 yuan ($2,229) for the 16 GB RAM + 512 GB storage version, while the 16 GB RAM + 1 TB storage model is 17,999 yuan ($2,508). The Samsung W25 Flip is priced at 9,999 yuan ($1,393). Both smartphones are available for pre-order and will go on sale in China on November 15.

Trump's victory sends shocks to world markets: Investor's Brief 07.11.24

November 7, 2024  09:13

Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election has sent shockwaves through global markets as traders expect drastic policy changes under the new administration. S&P 500 futures rose 2.2%, the dollar had its biggest gain since 2020 and bitcoin hit a record high. U.S. Treasuries fell on expectations of faster inflation, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury rose 20 basis points to 4.65%. Tesla shares rose more than 12% in premarket trading on the morning of Nov. 6 amid Trump's victory. Let's remind that Tesla CEO Elon Musk actively supported Trump during the election campaign.

US consumer spending rose slightly more than expected in September, putting the economy on an even higher growth trajectory ahead of the final quarter of the year. Consumer spending, which accounts for more than ⅔ of US economic activity, rose 0.5% last month, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis reported. In September, compared to September last year, consumer spending increased by 3.7%, which is the highest indicator of annual growth in 2023. after the first trimester.

Activity in the US service sector unexpectedly accelerated in October, reaching a more than two-year high, and the employment level strengthened, which once again proves that the US economy is currently in a fairly strong state. The Institute for Supply Management announced on November 6 that its non-manufacturing PMI index rose to 56 in October, up from 54.9 in the previous month. It is the highest level recorded since August. Earlier, economists polled by Reuters had forecast the services PMI to fall to 53.8. a sign of expansion in the overall economy.

The U.S. 30-year mortgage rate rose 21 basis points to 6.73% last week, the Mortgage Bankers Association said.The prime mortgage rate is now 60 basis points higher than it was in mid-September. after the central bank cut the refinancing rate by half a percentage point and announced an expected new But mortgage rates soon started to rise again as stronger-than-expected economic indicators, including rising consumer spending and job growth, allayed recessionary concerns, and the Federal Reserve is now expected to taper more slowly than expected. interest rates.

Contracts for the purchase of secondary market houses in the US increased by 7.4% in September. The National Association of Realtors said its index of pending home sales, which is based on a measure of signed purchase contracts, rose to 75.8. This is the largest increase recorded in more than four years. In August of this year, this index was 70.6. Meanwhile, economists polled by Reuters had predicted that home purchase contracts, which typically become sales contracts after a month or two, would increase by just 1 percent. According to economists, the reason for such a sharp increase is that buyers rushed to take advantage of the relatively low mortgage interest rates recorded at the end of the summer.

US job growth stalled in October, mainly due to aviation industry strikes and hurricanes. According to the Labor Department report, the unemployment rate remained at 4.1% in October. And the number of new jobs opened in August and September has been revised and is 112,000 less than previously reported.

According to a Reuters poll of nearly 500 economists, global economic growth will maintain its high pace next year as major central banks cut refinancing rates amid a strong US economy. Economists expect global economic growth to average 3.1% this year, a sharp improvement from the 2.6% forecast in January. It is the strong indicators of the US economy that have forced economists to revise their forecasts for global growth in 2024. Inflation has also fallen sharply, as most major central banks are now able to successfully manage inflationary pressures.

The cyber-secure world of the future: What will it look like and what role will AI play? Discussion

November 6, 2024  17:19

How will security threats evolve in the virtual world of the future, how can artificial intelligence (AI) strengthen cyber security and what risks does it pose, which global cooperation models are most effective for security management and what innovations will help protect critical infrastructure in 2050. The panel discussion under the title "Cyber-secure world of the future" organized within the framework of the "Creating the Future" symposium held in Moscow on November 4-6 was dedicated to these topics.

Andrey Masalovich, the founder of the modern school of internet intelligence in Russia, the creator of the Avalanche search system, the president of the Inforus consortium, referring to issues related to cyber security in the future, presented several possible technological trends, which, according to him, will be relevant in the near future. The first is that by the summer of 2025 ChatGPT will have problems because there will not be enough data to teach the neural network new things. Secondly, there will be a large number of attacks on important information infrastructures in the future.

According to Andrey Masalovich's next scenario, artificial intelligence (AI) integration will take place in the future and AI will be prepared for hacking attacks. Fourth, AI will be integrated into intelligence. Fifth, an autonomous weapon will appear, which will work with AI. According to him, such experience already exists. Sixth, multi-agent AI systems and swarm (group) AI systems will emerge (swarm intelligence - studies the collective behavior of a decentralized self-organizing system). Seventh, the necessary environment for development and use of AI will be created.

In addition, according to him, algorithms will appear in the future that will analyze the reliability of data, this will also apply to the cases of deepfake. Ninth, there will be a transition to Kolmogorov-Arnold type neural networks. According to Masalovich, those who will be able to build neural networks on this model now will see that they are several times more compact and fast. The tenth and most important trend, according to him, will be the loss of digital privacy, which AI will bring with it. "Get over it," he said.

Rustam Huseinov, an information security expert and the president of the RAD KOP cyber security specialists' cooperative, says that in each period there are trends characteristic of a specific region, and the capabilities of humanity are often overestimated. For example, judging by the sentiments of a few decades ago, it was possible to predict that in the 2000s, humanity should have set foot on the planet Mars, but this is not the case, because predictions do not always come true.

Rustam Huseinov says that considering the kind of changeable, complicated and complicated world we live in now, he will refrain from making predictions about either positive or negative scenarios. According to him, it should also be taken into account that there is no sector that operates separately and independently. all are interrelated, and when making any forecast, different areas should be taken into account, because there may be independently observable developments in this or that area, which will affect our forecast. According to him, it should be remembered that if any prediction about the future is made based on one or two spheres, there is a high probability that it will be wrong, it will not come true. "And we often forget about it," he said.

Predrag Čeranić, Doctor of Defense and Security Sciences, Dean of the Security Faculty of the University of Banja Luka presented the possible scenarios for the future. According to him, in the future, when technologies develop even more, more realistic virtual individuals appear, the theft of personal data may take on a different nature. According to him, since the prices of virtual property and digital assets are increasing, they will become the main target of cyber crimes.

"In a virtual world, where people communicate and exchange information with virtual avatars, the threats of social engineering will increase, which will aim to exploit people's emotions, behavior and trust," he said.

According to Predrag Čeranić, malicious software and "intelligent cyber threats" can appear thanks to advanced AI. As people begin to work in virtual environments, participate in social interactions and daily activities, the data collection process will include biometrics, eye tracking, movement models and personal interactions.

"The virtual world can offer new possibilities that can be used to track and taunt people. Criminals can use the immersive functions of technology to create dangerous situations for other people," he said.

In the future, he said, attackers could attack the underlying infrastructure of virtual worlds by launching DDoS attacks or malware that destabilize the network of servers that host massive interconnected virtual environments users see or hear in real life As businesses operate in virtual worlds, espionage and corporate espionage can target digital areas to gain competitive advantage.

In the future, according to Predrag Čeranić, AI will be used even more to increase cyber security. However, along with it, AI can bring risks with it, for example, cyber attacks using AI itself, or sometimes sophisticated AI algorithms can raise a false alarm. According to him, states should be involved in the fight against cyber security, exchange programs of experts in the field should be implemented, legislative mechanisms should be implemented and new ones should be developed if necessary.

Speaking about what innovations could be used to protect critical infrastructure by 2050, he noted that quantum computing is expected to change traditional encryption methods, which is why quantum stable cryptographic algorithms will be crucial. Blockchain technology will offer a reliable way to ensure the protection of critical infrastructure.

Writer, futurist, senior technical marketing manager of Kaspersky Lab, Aleksey Andreev, says that perhaps the main problem with cyber security is widespread access to the Internet, the ability to be constantly connected. He compared the situation to the last century, when they began to gradually use more sugar in various products, and as a result, the sugar industry developed. However, it brought with it a number of diseases, as a result of which a separate industry in medicine developed, which began to deal with these diseases.

Alexey Andreev singled out three trends of the future, which, according to him, are important. The first is universal spying. If in the past people were spied on by the special services, now who knows? The second trend, according to him, will be that people will be carried away by AI technologies. "The AI ​​boom has been over for a long time, around the last century, because all the AI ​​algorithms that are used now were created in the last century. The last 25 years are the marketing period of AI. AI is served to us with different sauces, and basically no one knows what AI is," he said.

According to him, people should be ready to live in an era where AI will be widely used, including in the field of cyber security. However, the same AI will regularly reveal problems that will not always be real and will cause unnecessary inconvenience to people. According to Alexey Andreev, in the next 20 years, people will live in a world where the AI will make many decisions. For example, a person will go to a bank, an embassy, ​​they will not give him a loan, a visa, and no one can answer why, because the decisions will be made by the AI, which takes into account thousands and millions of parameters. "You have to be psychologically ready for it," he added.

The third trend, he says, will be that the Internet we use today will one day no longer exist, instead there will be several different Internets, and from a cybersecurity perspective, that's probably for the better, because if a problem occurs today with today's Internet, there will be no alternative.

"If everyone has a Microsoft Windows operating system installed, if there's a vulnerability in it, all the people's computers running Microsoft Windows will crash," he said, citing an incident this year when Counter Strike updated its code. , and computers running on Windows failed, as a result, the work of a number of airports and factories stopped. Therefore, according to him, it is much better to have different networks, different security systems.

Mozilla lays off 30% of employees and closes one division

November 6, 2024  15:14

The Mozilla Foundation, the owner of the Mozilla Corporation subsidiary that developed the Firefox browser, has laid off 30% of its staff and closed its public advocacy department, saying it needs to focus on more pressing issues and develop a unified strategy across the organization, due to with the "relentless pressure of changes".

Brandon Borman, head of communications at the Mozilla Foundation, confirmed to TechCrunch that the organization had to take this step to increase its efficiency.

“The Mozilla Foundation is reorganizing the team to accelerate efforts to ensure a more inclusive and equitable technology future for all of us. "Unfortunately, that means we're putting some of our traditional projects on hold and eliminating relevant positions to focus on more important issues," the statement said.

At the moment, the company has 120 employees, which was confirmed by a source familiar with the situation. A Mozilla spokesperson did not dispute the data, nor the fact that this is Mozilla's second cut in a year. Previously, the employees of the department developing the popular Firefox browser were fired.

Mozilla includes the Mozilla Corporation, which develops the Firefox browser and other services, and the non-profit foundation that oversees Mozilla's corporate governance structure and sets Firefox policies, focused primarily on protecting privacy and decentralization technologies. , as well as "creating a safer and more transparent online space for everyone."

On October 30, Mozilla Foundation Executive Director Nabiha Syed confirmed in an email to employees the closure of the foundation's two main divisions: Advocacy and Global Programs. "Our mission at Mozilla is more important today than ever," Syed wrote. "We are under constant pressure to change in technology and other areas, and the idea of ​​putting people before profit seems increasingly radical to us."

Which Apple devices are users most satisfied with?

November 6, 2024  13:43

The developers of the AnTuTu benchmark have published the October user satisfaction ranking for various Apple devices, revealing that the company's latest smartphone performed worse than an older, less successful model.

Topping the list is the iPad Air 4 with the Apple A14 Bionic chip, receiving 96.55% positive feedback in October.

Following closely is the iPhone 12 mini, which pleased 95.96% of its owners. Interestingly, this model is considered one of Apple's commercial missteps. Its weak sales and Apple’s subsequent decision to abandon mini smartphones in favor of Plus versions only confirm this.

The third spot is held by the 11-inch iPad Pro with the Apple A12X chip, boasting a 95.82% satisfaction rate.

In fourth and fifth places are the 11-inch iPad Pro (95.13%) and the 12.9-inch version (95%), both powered by the Apple A12Z Bionic chip.

The budget-friendly iPhone SE (2020) claims the sixth spot, with 94.95% of users satisfied. Next in line is the 11-inch iPad Pro with the Apple M1 chip, earning 94.77% positive feedback.

The new iPhone 16 Pro only made it to eighth place, garnering 94.43% positive reviews. Rounding out the top devices are the iPad Air 5 and iPad mini 5, with 93.66% and 93.38% positive feedback, respectively.

AnTuTu emphasized that the ranking is based on online user reviews, with higher scores awarded to devices with more five-star ratings.

WhatsApp adds new feature

November 6, 2024  11:51

The popular messenger WhatsApp has expanded its capabilities by adding the function of lists of users in the chat. This innovative solution will help users quickly find the chat they need and organize their correspondence. With this function, it is possible to create lists for different categories of chatters, which will be displayed at the top of the screen. Information about this feature appeared on the official WhatsApp blog.

The new function is intended for those who have difficulty finding the necessary dialog. Users will now be able to create lists with Work, Family, and other names that will sit next to the All, Groups, and Unread filters.

To create a list, you need to click the Plus icon in the filter bar, then enter a name and choose which chats to add to the new list. This will allow you to add both individual and group chats. If you have multiple lists, users will be able to scroll the row horizontally.

WhatsApp is an American free messaging and voice communication service owned by Meta. It enables users to exchange text and voice messages, make voice and video calls, share images and other data. More than 2 billion people worldwide use WhatsApp every month.

Bitcoin hits an all-time high of $75,000

November 6, 2024  09:50

Bitcoin cryptocurrency has set a new exchange rate record, reaching $75,000. In just one hour, the increase made an impressive 10%, showing the strongest upward dynamics since the beginning of the year.

Such a sharp increase was facilitated by the ongoing presidential elections in the USA, in which the Republican candidate Donald Trump, who has a positive position on the issue of cryptocurrencies, is leading at the moment.

The New York Times analytical system estimates the probability of Donald Trump's victory at 71%, which caused a strong reaction in the cryptocurrency market.

The Polymarket platform gives an even more optimistic forecast, where the probability of Trump's victory is estimated at 90%. It appears that market participants are already factoring this scenario into the Bitcoin price, reacting with active buying.

The final results of the election have not been published yet, but the cryptocurrency market is already reacting to the preliminary data.

I believe that buildings of the future do not have to stand still։ James Law

November 5, 2024  20:15

James Law is a visionary architect, who designs cyberhomes in India and China. The interview was conducted on the eve of the scientific symposium titled “Creating the Future” held in Moscow on November 4-6. NEWS.am is the information sponsor of the symposium.

You coined the term “Cybertecture.” Can you explain what it means and how it influences your architectural designs?

The philosophy of cybertecture comes from a belief that I have, that humanity is going to be building our civilization out of more than the traditional materials of our planet. We are now using new materials like artificial intelligence. We are using new scientific discoveries. And so from the typical world of architecture, where we are making things out of the typical materials of our planet, I've derived this philosophy a word called “Cybertecture” to embody this whole new humanity where we will be building out of the new and creative and digital and intelligent materials that is now being available to us.

How do you envision the future of urban living, and what role does Cybertecture play in shaping that vision?

Well, first of all, when we talk about cities, cities are already inhabited by more than half of the world's population, and as we know, increasingly, there will be more and more billions of people moving to the cities. The planet may even become one giant city one day. So cities are the greatest and the largest and the most complex technology that man is currently designing and building. Therefore, our belief at cybertecture is that these future cities must be designed, built and operated in an entirely different way. Traditional cities where people just live and work in there has created many problems, like overpopulation, crowdedness, traffic, pollution, etc. And so what cybertecture is trying to do is to reinvent what it means to be a city. We believe that the cities of the future are giant pieces of tech.

Technology on this planet that will be powering itself in a sustainable way, keeping citizens safe, educated and employed, and most importantly, be a kind of treasure trove for all of the knowledge and culture that humanity has accumulated. So at cybertecture, we are really researching and designing as much as possible with the latest technologies, integrating them into the city. So how we power city, how we plan the city, how we run the city, how we build a city, will be based on an entirely new level of operating system. And I think this is the dawn of a new era in what we mean by cities on this planet.

Your projects like the tube house and mobile cities are groundbreaking. How do you believe such concepts reshape our understanding of “home” and “city” in the modern world?

So our projects such as our moving cities are really a kind of investigation and awakening to the fact that all of the typical things that we expect from a city will change and will change very quickly. We are already, for example, for many decades, flying in an aircraft, which essentially is a building that can fly from continent to continent. So why can buildings not also do the same thing? Why can cities not move in the same way? We really believe that innovative projects and concepts like this not only test what we have taken for granted to be the only way of doing things, but open up our minds to the new possibilities of achieving new levels of life and new levels of society.

We really believe that buildings do not have to stand still. They can be very much like an electric car. They can be a much bigger, changeable, transformable structure, and in doing so match with the changing climate and conditions of our ever changing world. Cities have become mired by the fact that they're old fashioned and they cannot change. So by being moving, by being transformable, by being upgradable, and by being more intelligent, I think cities will become a new kind of machine for us all to live in.

You have envisioned cities that can move to new locations. What sparked this idea, and how do you think it could address urban problems like overpopulation and environmental degradation?

So I think environmental degradation, including global warming, is really changing the condition upon which human beings are living on this planet. We are suddenly getting massive storms that attack our settlements. We have floods; we even may have earthquakes, wildfires and also generally temperatures, which are no longer comfortable for us to live and for our agriculture to really be sustained. Therefore, we must ask ourselves, how we will continue to live on this planet if such big, systemic catastrophes could happen at any time. If we are not flexible, resilient, and intelligent, we will become the victims of this condition.

So projects, which look at how our settlements not only move but adapt to this changing condition, is the only way for us to keep growing. Sometimes, when a part of our planet becomes inhabitable, we cannot fight that condition. We must become nomads once again to find the fertile and better climate for our future generations. So this is, I think, the new condition that urban living is now facing, which is that whatever we are creating is a victim of the conditions of the climate and of the politics and of the economics. So maybe we need to be more intelligent in our urban design, so that our lives can be still, as wonderful as before, but not necessarily in one place that we will be migrating from place to place throughout our lives in a sustainable way.

The Cybertecture Egg in Mumbai is one of your flagship projects. What were the biggest challenges in designing and constructing this energy-efficient structure?

A project like the Cybertecture Egg was extremely challenging, because what we had to do was to break the typical, conventional way in which we design architecture. So first of all, the building was not conceived purely as a building. We wanted to conceive it as a second nature, that this structure will almost have some of the intelligence of nature. How do we achieve this? We needed to use very difficult, sophisticated computer software to help us develop a shape and a structure that would be much more efficient in the climate.

So the shape is not just for novelty. The shape is like a plant growing from that particular site, capturing just the right amount of sun, creating just enough space inside for the functions of the building, married with a very intelligent and sophisticated structure that allows the building to have no columns. This is a kind of high level design that we often see in nature. We admire the organic shapes of flowers and plants. We marvel at how nature can always find the right way to get its right resources and live in the most efficient way. We apply the same challenge to making a piece of architecture like the cybertecture aid so the difficulty was how to bridge between architecture and the sophistication of nature, and by using technologies like computer aided design, we're starting to bring the two together to create a next generation of second nature architecture.


Why did you decide to participate in the International Science Fiction Symposium ‘Creating the Future’? What will your presentation focus on?

So I'm very honored to be invited to be part of this amazing event. The reason why I am really looking forward to be part of this event is that, fundamentally, I share the same philosophy. As a child, I was always very, very interested in science fiction, and I believe that science fiction, actually, apart from it being entertaining, is an intellectual way for us to creatively speculate about the future, which actually is very important. Sometimes we have to ask ourselves, how do we invent the future? The only way, sometimes, is to speculate and to kind of elaborate on the vision that speculates on what can be done in the future. So that is science fiction.

And I think at the heart of what I'm doing at cybertecture is, in fact, science fiction becoming real, using the power of science fiction to look at the solutions for a better possible future. So being part of this event allows me, of course, to share in my own experiences and direction, but also to interact and meet many of the leading thoughts, thinkers in the field of science fiction, so that I can really, of course, learn from them, but that we can also share many ideas.

In my own particular presentations I will be showing several things. One is, I'll be showing a series of futuristic city designs that are really changing the entire DNA of what the city can be in order for us to be forward looking and avoid the problems of the past. I'll also be showing some of the inspirations behind my work, some of my childhood influences from science fiction that has really become almost real in my work in the decades since. So it's quite nice for me to share my journey in science fiction and becoming a cybertech, designing cybertecture.

I think that I like to say that at this era in time, our entire world is facing incredible challenges, and these challenges are on the scale that is beyond any particular company, beyond any particular country. It's a global effort, and this global effort is both in the thoughts of the mind as well as in the economy and in the industry and in the science. Faced with these challenges, I think humanity has the kind of moment in time to show how wonderful we can react to these challenges, and by being creative and forward looking, being futuristic, we can change these challenges into opportunities that will raise up the entire world on the level that has never been seen before. We are at the dawn of the era of AI we are at the dawn of the era of quantum computing. We are at dawn of the era of space travel. These are doors that are getting wider and wider for us to step through and to utilize in how we can create a better humanity for the eons to come. So my message is, let us all be brave. Let us all be courageous. Let us all be visionary and really embrace this opportunity of the future so that we do not make the mistakes of the past again.


Do you think humanity is succeeding or failing in facing those challenges that you mentioned?

I think humanity's journey is one where we both fail and succeed. It is a duality. There is no continuous failure, neither is the continuous success. We are riding waves of change, both good and bad, wars, pandemics, economic growth, prosperity; all of them are mixed in the kind of strange, chaotic frequency as we move ahead. However, if we don't keep moving ahead, we may become stuck in an unhealthy frequency. And so I believe that as long as humanity continues to move ahead in a positive, courageous, visionary way, any of the problems that we're facing now will become temporary, and the chances of us having a positive outcome will increase so we are both winning and losing. But that is not the issue. The issue is we should keep moving forwards.

Artificial Intelligence: Competitor or an ally for man?

November 5, 2024  16:43

Will there be a conflict between artificial intelligence (AI) and humans, or will they complement each other and AI will become a helper in all matters, is AI the future of civilization or its killer, will the world have another technological revolution, is AI a new zone of international confrontation or a basis for cooperation? These and a number of other topics were discussed during the the panel discussion entitled titleed "Artificial Intelligence: Competitor or Ally?" and organized within the framework of the "Creating the Future" symposium held in Moscow on November 4-6.

Andrey Neznamov, managing director of the human-centered AI center of Sberbank CJSC, chairman of the Russian National Commission for the introduction of the code of ethics in the AI sector, says that technologies are constantly developing, bringing with them changes that become common after a while. For example, if people used to travel long distances by horse, later the car and other means of transport were created, and people started moving with them. Of course, many people remained unemployed in the field of horse breeding, because there was no previous demand, and began to specialize in other fields, which, according to him, is natural, because development brings changes with it.

"Artificial intelligence is becoming an integral part of our lives, and it is often quite difficult to respond to the changes that AI brings with it," he said, adding that, in his opinion, AI is an ally, not a competitor.

He mentioned that specific professions are disappearing, people are losing their jobs, and in some cases this is really inevitable. "After that, it's very simple to do: does a person update his knowledge or not?" Does it take a new tool or not? It's not a competition with AI, it's a competition between people who start using AI and those who don't,” he said.

Science fiction writer, IT specialist Eldar Safin says that everything depends on the settings, because the same car, bus or other means of transport, which are the product of the development of science, apart from benefiting people, they also have negative aspects, or can be used for bad purposes. For example, thousands of people die in car accidents every year, or the same cars are used in different crimes, or people commit traffic violations.

"Sometimes we talk about small things, small violations, but when we talk about AI, it has a much bigger scale. AI can affect the whole world, and sometimes we may not know about it. There may be one violation, but the consequences will be big," he said.

Iridium OJSC chief designer Igor Koptelov says that how advanced science is, its fruits can be so good and at the same time terrible, especially if they end up in the hands of the wrong people. As an example, he cites nuclear weapons and nuclear energy, when energy benefits humanity, and weapons cause destruction.

According to him, AI is a great helper today and contributes to the development of various fields, starting from medicine and ending with cloud services, this is an undeniable fact, but everything depends on the purpose for which it is used. Specifically, their company uses AI to optimize the process of deploying virtual machines in cloud services, and using AI allows up to 30% savings.

Koptelov also mentioned that in their company, in the next stage, they will already apply AI in the direction of reducing or reducing the human participation in these processes to zero. Observing that it is also bad news for the professionals who are doing this work today, because they will be fired, Koptelov said that this is natural, because everything changes, some professions disappear and new ones appear. new ones, and people have to adapt to new realities. According to him, there is no question of competition here, science is developing, life is changing, it was like that in all stages of history, just now everything is happening a little faster.

According to Igor Koptelov, AI is used in a number of fields in one way or another. "It is no longer possible to give up on it, but it is necessary to control it," he said.

Science fiction writer Eldar Safin disagrees that there is no competition with the advent of AI. "To say that AI is not a competitor is a bit strange," he said, citing last year's protest by screenwriters in Los Angeles to ban the use of the large ChatGPT language model in full screenplays, which they won. in the struggle. Safin also mentioned that he has known illustrators who report that their work has been significantly reduced, and that workers in this field are gradually being phased out of the market because the Midjourney neural network is already doing most of the work and faster.

"The same applies to copywriters. In the near future, this will also apply to architects... composers... Learning to prompt AI is much easier than years of learning to draw or write music. It turns out that complete schools of knowledge will disappear in the near future," he said, adding that they will disappear especially in small settlements, because no one will need them in that amount, and they will continue to function in big cities.

Nevertheless, he believes that in the long run, AI will be an ally for man, but a competitor for mankind. "Because now we are solving AI tasks that we can. And in the future, with the help of AI, we will solve the tasks that we can give to AI, but we cannot perform, and AI can. Imagine that a person is in a situation where a tool is smarter than him. It is good that there are rules, it is good that these rules are followed. But will everyone always follow those rules?" he said, adding that he doesn't think so.

Futurologist, engineer José Luis Cordeiro says that such a discussion is pointless, because AI has been a reality for a long time and everything will actually be very good, another thing is that some people may not like the changes brought by AI. However, it is not important, because life will go on regardless of everything without those people.

"AI will not be stopped, it will no longer be possible to go back. Who wants to go back to a world where there are no mobile phones, cars, trains, planes? No one would want to return to such a primitive world... I want to be smarter. Of course, it would be good if it happened naturally, but if you can have AI to be smarter, then you should use it," he said.

José Cordeiro stated that he is not afraid of AI, instead he is afraid of the stupid things that people do and can do, he is afraid of people who avoid changes, cling to the past and do not want to move forward.

"AI is the best invention of mankind. It is what will push us forward into the future, will solve all the problems that we have not yet solved. For example, why is there poverty, hunger, wars, etc. today, because we are stupid? When we become smarter, we will already live in a world that will be better, richer, cleaner, more peaceful. And for that we need more intelligence," he said, adding that humanity should use AI to make the world a better place.

Igor Chubarov, Director of the School of Meta-disciplinary Competences, Vice-Rector of Tyumen State University, Director of the Cultural Studies Department of the Moscow Institute of Psychoanalysis, considers it natural that AI causes a number of concerns among people, because in many cases it directly affects people's lives. Nevertheless, according to him, it is necessary to help people to accept the changes brought by AI and adapt to the new realities.

Chubarov believes that AI is an ally for those who already use AI to some extent and makes some positive observations about the limitations of this technology and offers options for its development. "And it is a competitor for those who feel that they are losing their place, positions in the fields of science, creativity, and management and feel that they have to update their knowledge," he said, adding that for many it is a serious problem. because people tend to work in areas where they have relevant knowledge and some experience and actually avoid change.

According to him, it is important to properly build relations with AI technologies. with conviction, a person should participate in the activities of application, training, and development of AI at his level, and those fears related to this will no longer be relevant. According to him, a person has such characteristics, for example, the ability to create, thanks to which AI can never replace a person in all areas.

According to Andrey Doudrich, head of the social research and consulting department of the All-Russian Center for the Study of Public Opinion (ВЦИОМ), before deciding whether AI is a person's ally or competitor, one must first understand what it is, and AI is a tool. which everyone should learn to use correctly. Secondly, by using AI, people should increase their work efficiency.

According to Dudrich, AI today really causes problems for many people, because people have to update their knowledge base, become more efficient in their work, and people are generally lazy and have a hard time learning new things, they have a hard time making changes.

He reminded that in the 90s, when mobile phones appeared, people were suspicious of them. "However, several decades have passed, and who now remembers himself without a phone, without communication?" See how much it has simplified our life, increased our efficiency," he said, adding that now humanity is going through a cycle of changes with AI and will gradually adapt to it.

"AI is our ally and helper. "AI should not replace a person in this or that field, but should help, make our work more effective," he said.

Andrey Daudrich also referred to people's attitude towards the use of AI in the field of education and presented some data from the surveys they conducted in Russia. According to these surveys, 1/3 of people believe that the use of AI in the field of education will increase the quality of education, 40% believe that it will decrease, and 1/5 of the hits believe that it will not affect the quality of education in any way. .
